trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Create a trail
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Create a trail

trans-unit.source: Intermediate Artist Programmer
trans-unit.target: Intermediate Artist Programmer

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrates how to use particles to create a trail effect for a sword swing.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrates how to use particles to create a trail effect for a sword swing.

trans-unit.source: 1. Create a project
trans-unit.target: 1. Create a project

trans-unit.source: In the Stride Launcher, click Start and select New Game.
trans-unit.target: In the Stride Launcher, click Start and select New Game.

trans-unit.source: In the Create a new game dialog, under Asset Packs, select Animated Models. The Animated Models pack contains assets we'll be using in this example. (Note that we'll make our particle effect from scratch.)
trans-unit.target: In the Create a new game dialog, under Asset Packs, select Animated Models. The Animated Models pack contains assets we'll be using in this example. (Note that we'll make our particle effect from scratch.)

trans-unit.source: Create a new game
trans-unit.target: Create a new game

trans-unit.source: Give the project a name (eg MyTrailEffect) and click OK. Game Studio loads a simple scene with a few entities.
trans-unit.target: Give the project a name (eg MyTrailEffect) and click OK. Game Studio loads a simple scene with a few entities.

trans-unit.source: We don't need the Sphere entity for this tutorial, so go ahead and delete it (select it and press Delete).
trans-unit.target: We don't need the Sphere entity for this tutorial, so go ahead and delete it (select it and press Delete).

trans-unit.target: 2. Set up the models and animation

trans-unit.source: In the Asset View, open the Models folder and drag and drop the mannequinModel into the scene. The mannequinModel contains a skeleton asset that we'll use for our sword slash animation.
trans-unit.target: In the Asset View, open the Models folder and drag and drop the mannequinModel into the scene. The mannequinModel contains a skeleton asset that we'll use for our sword slash animation.

trans-unit.source: With the mannequinModel selected, in the Property Grid, select Add component > Animations. This adds an Animation component to the model.
trans-unit.target: With the mannequinModel selected, in the Property Grid, select Add component > Animations. This adds an Animation component to the model.

trans-unit.target: Add Animations

trans-unit.source: Now let's give the mannequin a weapon. In the Asset View, browse to the Models folder and drag the SwordModel to the mannequinModel in the Entity Tree. This makes the SwordModel a child entity of the mannequinModel.
trans-unit.target: Now let's give the mannequin a weapon. In the Asset View, browse to the Models folder and drag the SwordModel to the mannequinModel in the Entity Tree. This makes the SwordModel a child entity of the mannequinModel.

trans-unit.target: SwordModel child entity

trans-unit.source: With the in the Property Grid, click Add component and select Model Node Link. This is called a Bone Link in some versions of Stride.
trans-unit.target: With the in the Property Grid, click Add component and select Model Node Link. This is called a Bone Link in some versions of Stride.

trans-unit.source: Add Model Node Link
trans-unit.target: Add Model Node Link

trans-unit.target: We can use this to link the SwordModel to a point in the mannequinModel skeleton. There's no need to specify a target, as the entity uses its parent entity (mannequinModel) by default.

trans-unit.target: We have a swinging sword animation. Next, let's add a trail effect.

trans-unit.source: 3. Create a basic trail
trans-unit.target: 3. Create a basic trail

trans-unit.source: First we'll build a basic trail, just to see how it looks.
trans-unit.target: First we'll build a basic trail, just to see how it looks.

trans-unit.source: In Game Studio, select the SwordModel. In the Property Grid, click Add component and select Particle System.
trans-unit.target: In Game Studio, select the SwordModel. In the Property Grid, click Add component and select Particle System.

trans-unit.source: Add Particle System
trans-unit.target: Add Particle System

trans-unit.source: This adds a particle system component to the model, which we'll use to build a trail effect.
trans-unit.target: This adds a particle system component to the model, which we'll use to build a trail effect.

trans-unit.source: Click Source to expand its properties.
trans-unit.target: Click Source to expand its properties.

trans-unit.source: Expand Source properties
trans-unit.target: Expand Source properties

trans-unit.source: Next to Emitters, click Green plus button (Add). This adds a new particle emitter.
trans-unit.target: Next to Emitters, click Green plus button (Add). This adds a new particle emitter.

trans-unit.source: Under the emitter properties, set the Shape to Trail.
trans-unit.target: Under the emitter properties, set the Shape to Trail.

trans-unit.source: Set Shape to Trail
trans-unit.target: Set Shape to Trail

trans-unit.source: Unfortunately, we need to make a brief detour due to a bug in Stride. Under the Shape properties, set the Axis to Center. (The shape should really be set to Edge, but the Edge and Center settings are reversed in the UI. This will be fixed in Stride 1.9.3.)
trans-unit.target: Unfortunately, we need to make a brief detour due to a bug in Stride. Under the Shape properties, set the Axis to Center. (The shape should really be set to Edge, but the Edge and Center settings are reversed in the UI. This will be fixed in Stride 1.9.3.)

trans-unit.source: Set Axis to Center
trans-unit.target: Set Axis to Center

trans-unit.source: Next to Spawners, click Green plus button (Add) and select Per frame.
trans-unit.target: Next to Spawners, click Green plus button (Add) and select Per frame.

trans-unit.source: Add per-frame spawner
trans-unit.target: Add per-frame spawner

trans-unit.source: This adds a per-frame spawner to the emitter, which spawns X number of particles per frame (as opposed to, say, per second).
trans-unit.target: This adds a per-frame spawner to the emitter, which spawns X number of particles per frame (as opposed to, say, per second).

trans-unit.source: Next to Initializers, click Green plus button (Add) and select Velocity.
trans-unit.target: Next to Initializers, click Green plus button (Add) and select Velocity.

trans-unit.source: Add velocity initializer
trans-unit.target: Add velocity initializer

trans-unit.source: This adds a velocity initializer to the emitter.
trans-unit.target: This adds a velocity initializer to the emitter.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you can grab the mannequin and move it around the scene to see how the particles behave. They look like a cloud of blocky smoke.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you can grab the mannequin and move it around the scene to see how the particles behave. They look like a cloud of blocky smoke.

trans-unit.source: Under the velocity initializer, set both the Velocity min and Velocity max values to 0, 5, 0.
trans-unit.target: Under the velocity initializer, set both the Velocity min and Velocity max values to 0, 5, 0.

trans-unit.source: Set velocity min and max
trans-unit.target: Set velocity min and max

trans-unit.source: This restricts the particles to the Y axis, like an infinitely thin sheet of paper.
trans-unit.target: This restricts the particles to the Y axis, like an infinitely thin sheet of paper.

trans-unit.source: Next to Initializers, click Green plus button (Add) and select Direction.
trans-unit.target: Next to Initializers, click Green plus button (Add) and select Direction.

trans-unit.source: Add direction initializer
trans-unit.target: Add direction initializer

trans-unit.source: This adds a direction initializer to the emitter.
trans-unit.target: This adds a direction initializer to the emitter.

trans-unit.source: Expand the direction initializer to view the properties. Set both the Direction min and Direction max to 0, 0, -1. This aligns the trail with the direction of the swing animation.
trans-unit.target: Expand the direction initializer to view the properties. Set both the Direction min and Direction max to 0, 0, -1. This aligns the trail with the direction of the swing animation.

trans-unit.source: Run the game to see how the particles look with the sword-swinging animation.
trans-unit.target: Run the game to see how the particles look with the sword-swinging animation.

trans-unit.source: We have a trail, but it doesn't look too good yet. It's too long, it's a single block of color, its particles interconnect strangely, and it never disappears.
trans-unit.target: We have a trail, but it doesn't look too good yet. It's too long, it's a single block of color, its particles interconnect strangely, and it never disappears.

trans-unit.source: 4. Sort the particles
trans-unit.target: 4. Sort the particles

trans-unit.source: Because the particles are rendered as billboards, the segments of the trail interconnect strangely. To create a proper trail effect, we need to sort the particles into an order by adding a spawn order initializer.
trans-unit.target: Because the particles are rendered as billboards, the segments of the trail interconnect strangely. To create a proper trail effect, we need to sort the particles into an order by adding a spawn order initializer.

trans-unit.source: In the SwordModel properties, under Particle System > Source > Emitters, next to Initializers, click Green plus button (Add) and select Spawn Order.
trans-unit.target: In the SwordModel properties, under Particle System > Source > Emitters, next to Initializers, click Green plus button (Add) and select Spawn Order.

trans-unit.source: !Note Make sure you don't select Spawn Order (Parent) or Spawn Order (Group).
trans-unit.target: !Note Make sure you don't select Spawn Order (Parent) or Spawn Order (Group).

trans-unit.source: Add spawn-order initializer
trans-unit.target: Add spawn-order initializer

trans-unit.source: This adds a spawn order initializer to the emitter. It doesn't have any properties, but it gives the particles a SpawnID we can sort them by.
trans-unit.target: This adds a spawn order initializer to the emitter. It doesn't have any properties, but it gives the particles a SpawnID we can sort them by.

trans-unit.source: Under Emitters, under Sorting, choose ByOrder.
trans-unit.target: Under Emitters, under Sorting, choose ByOrder.

trans-unit.source: Sort by order
trans-unit.target: Sort by order

trans-unit.source: Under Initalizers, under the Velocity initializer, change both the Velocity min and Velocity max values to 0,0.5,0.
trans-unit.target: Under Initalizers, under the Velocity initializer, change both the Velocity min and Velocity max values to 0,0.5,0.

trans-unit.source: Change velocity
trans-unit.target: Change velocity

trans-unit.source: Run the game.
trans-unit.target: Run the game.

trans-unit.source: Now the particles move cohesively.
trans-unit.target: Now the particles move cohesively.

trans-unit.source: 5. Change the length
trans-unit.target: 5. Change the length

trans-unit.source: In the SwordModel properties, under Particle System > Source > Emitters, change the Lifespan to 0.2, 0.2.
trans-unit.target: In the SwordModel properties, under Particle System > Source > Emitters, change the Lifespan to 0.2, 0.2.

trans-unit.source: Change emitter lifespan
trans-unit.target: Change emitter lifespan

trans-unit.source: Move the mannequin around the scene and notice how the trails extinguish more quickly.
trans-unit.target: Move the mannequin around the scene and notice how the trails extinguish more quickly.

trans-unit.target: 6. Add a texture

trans-unit.target: Add a texture

trans-unit.target: In the SwordModel properties, expand Emitters > Material. Click Hand icon (Select an asset). Browse to the Textures folder and select swoosh.png.

trans-unit.source: Add material texture
trans-unit.target: Add material texture

trans-unit.source: Set the Alpha-Add bar to 1, so it's 100% emissive.

trans-unit.target: Set UV

trans-unit.target: Expand UV Rotate. Under Clockwise, select 90 degrees. This rotates the texture 90 degrees clockwise, so the "swoosh" lines point in the right direction.

trans-unit.target: Rotate material

trans-unit.source: We're getting closer. But the trail doesn't disappear, so it looks like it's attached to the sword. We need to make the effect appear when the mannequin swings, then disappear at the end of the swing.

trans-unit.source: 7. Make the particle effect a prefab
trans-unit.target: 7. Make the particle effect a prefab

trans-unit.source: So far, we've created a particle effect by attaching it as a component to the sword. Now we're going to separate the effect from the sword and make it an independent entity we can turn on and off when we like. To do this, we'll create a prefab. For more information about prefabs, see the prefab documentation.
trans-unit.target: So far, we've created a particle effect by attaching it as a component to the sword. Now we're going to separate the effect from the sword and make it an independent entity we can turn on and off when we like. To do this, we'll create a prefab. For more information about prefabs, see the prefab documentation.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the SwordModel and select Create prefab from selection.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the SwordModel and select Create prefab from selection.

trans-unit.source: Create prefab from selection
trans-unit.target: Create prefab from selection

trans-unit.source: Game Studio creates a prefab from the SwordModel and adds it to the Asset View. By creating a prefab from the selection, we can quickly copy over the options we've set up so far.
trans-unit.target: Game Studio creates a prefab from the SwordModel and adds it to the Asset View. By creating a prefab from the selection, we can quickly copy over the options we've set up so far.

trans-unit.source: We don't want the SwordModel itself to be a prefab — we just used it as a template to create the prefab from. It should be separate from our new particle effect prefab, so right-click it and select Break link to prefab.
trans-unit.target: We don't want the SwordModel itself to be a prefab — we just used it as a template to create the prefab from. It should be separate from our new particle effect prefab, so right-click it and select Break link to prefab.

trans-unit.target: Break link to prefab

trans-unit.source: Because naming things properly makes everything easier, rename the prefab SwordTrail. To do this, in the Asset View, right-click the SwordModel prefab, select Rename, and type SwordTrail.
trans-unit.target: Because naming things properly makes everything easier, rename the prefab SwordTrail. To do this, in the Asset View, right-click the SwordModel prefab, select Rename, and type SwordTrail.

trans-unit.target: Rename prefab

trans-unit.source: Prefab Editor
trans-unit.target: Prefab Editor

trans-unit.source: The prefab contains just one entity, SwordModel. It's not going to be a model for much longer, so let's rename this entity SwordTrail (the same as the prefab it belongs to).
trans-unit.target: The prefab contains just one entity, SwordModel. It's not going to be a model for much longer, so let's rename this entity SwordTrail (the same as the prefab it belongs to).

trans-unit.source: Remove the Model and the Model Node Link (or Bone Link) components from the SwordTrail entity. We don't need them any more — this prefab will just be a particle effect.
trans-unit.target: Remove the Model and the Model Node Link (or Bone Link) components from the SwordTrail entity. We don't need them any more — this prefab will just be a particle effect.

trans-unit.source: Likewise, under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Initializers, delete the Velocity initializer. For now, we want the prefab effect to be static.
trans-unit.target: Likewise, under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Initializers, delete the Velocity initializer. For now, we want the prefab effect to be static.

trans-unit.source: Delete velocity initializer
trans-unit.target: Delete velocity initializer

trans-unit.source: In the SwordTrail properties, under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Spawners, set Loop to One shot and change Duration to 0.2, 0.2.
trans-unit.target: In the SwordTrail properties, under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Spawners, set Loop to One shot and change Duration to 0.2, 0.2.

trans-unit.source: Set the initializer loop and duration
trans-unit.target: Set the initializer loop and duration

trans-unit.source: Now we've created a separate prefab for the particle effect, we don't need to keep a particle effect on the sword model. In the main scene, select SwordModel and delete the Particle System component.
trans-unit.target: Now we've created a separate prefab for the particle effect, we don't need to keep a particle effect on the sword model. In the main scene, select SwordModel and delete the Particle System component.

trans-unit.target: 8. Control the effect prefab with a script

trans-unit.target: We've created a sword trail effect prefab. Next we'll use a script to spawn the effect every time the mannequin swings and delete the effect a few frames later.

trans-unit.source: 10. Curve the trail
trans-unit.target: 10. Curve the trail

trans-unit.source: In the SwordTrail prefab, on the SwordTrail entity, under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Shape, set Smoothing to Best and Segments to 5.
trans-unit.target: In the SwordTrail prefab, on the SwordTrail entity, under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Shape, set Smoothing to Best and Segments to 5.

trans-unit.source: Smoothing and segments
trans-unit.target: Smoothing and segments

trans-unit.source: This adds three vertices between the particles of our trail, which should be enough to create a noticeably smoother effect.
trans-unit.target: This adds three vertices between the particles of our trail, which should be enough to create a noticeably smoother effect.

trans-unit.source: Run the game.
trans-unit.target: Run the game.

trans-unit.source: The inner curve, at the sword hilt, is smoother. But the curve at the sword's edge is still jagged.
trans-unit.target: The inner curve, at the sword hilt, is smoother. But the curve at the sword's edge is still jagged.

trans-unit.source: Smoothed and unsmoothed areas
trans-unit.target: Smoothed and unsmoothed areas

trans-unit.source: We want to smooth the effect at the sword's edge, where it's more noticeable. To do that, we'll flip the particle direction.
trans-unit.target: We want to smooth the effect at the sword's edge, where it's more noticeable. To do that, we'll flip the particle direction.

trans-unit.source: Still in the SwordTrail prefab, in the Transform component properties, change the Position to 0, 0, -1.
trans-unit.target: Still in the SwordTrail prefab, in the Transform component properties, change the Position to 0, 0, -1.

trans-unit.source: Swordtrail position
trans-unit.target: Swordtrail position

trans-unit.source: This moves the starting point of the particle effect to the tip of the sword.
trans-unit.target: This moves the starting point of the particle effect to the tip of the sword.

trans-unit.source: Run the game.
trans-unit.target: Run the game.

trans-unit.source: Now we have a new problem. Because we moved the particle effect to the tip of the sword, the particles are flying from the tip. We need to reverse their direction, so they move down along the sword blade to the hilt.
trans-unit.target: Now we have a new problem. Because we moved the particle effect to the tip of the sword, the particles are flying from the tip. We need to reverse their direction, so they move down along the sword blade to the hilt.

trans-unit.source: Under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Initializers, under the Direction initializer, change both the Direction min and Direction max to 0, 0, 1. This inverts the trail direction.
trans-unit.target: Under Particle System > Source > Emitters > Initializers, under the Direction initializer, change both the Direction min and Direction max to 0, 0, 1. This inverts the trail direction.

trans-unit.source: Initializer direction
trans-unit.target: Initializer direction

trans-unit.source: Run the game.
trans-unit.target: Run the game.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You created a trail effect from scratch. How you tweak it now is up to you.
trans-unit.target: Congratulations! You created a trail effect from scratch. How you tweak it now is up to you.
